unnormalised: What are some essential things to know before traveling by Indian Railways?
normalised: Travelling by Indian Railways is a unique experience! It’s how millions of Indians get around, and understanding the system can make your journey smoother. First, familiarize yourself with the different train classes. You'll see options like one A, two A, three A (A C classes), S L (Sleeper Class), and two S (Second Seating). The prices vary significantly, with a one A ticket from Delhi to Mumbai costing upwards of rupee five thousand, while an S L ticket on the same route might be around rupees eight hundred.

normalised: Booking tickets can be done online via the I-R-C-T-C website or app. Tatkal tickets, which are for urgent travel, open at ten A M for A C classes and eleven A M for non-A C classes, one day before the journey. However, be warned, they get sold out extremely fast. Also, make sure to carry a valid I D proof like your Aadhaar card or Voter I D. The T-T-E (Travelling Ticket Examiner) will need to verify it.

unnormalised: Booking tickets can be done online via the IRCTC website or app. Tatkal tickets, which are for urgent travel, open at 10:00 AM for AC classes and 11:00 AM for non-AC classes, one day before the journey. However, be warned, they get sold out extremely fast. Also, make sure to carry a valid ID proof like your Aadhaar card or Voter ID. The TTE (Travelling Ticket Examiner) will need to verify it.
normalised: Understanding the train schedule is crucial. Trains often run late, especially during the monsoon season. Use apps like RailYatri or N-T-E-S (National Train Enquiry System) to track your train’s live location. For example, the Punjab Mail, train number one two one three seven, is frequently delayed by two to three hours, especially in the winter months due to fog. Platform numbers are usually announced thirty minutes before arrival, but always double-check the displays at the station.

normalised: Food on trains can be a hit or miss. While I-R-C-T-C offers e-catering services, it's always a good idea to carry your own snacks and water. Many vendors sell chai and snacks on the platforms at prices ranging from rupees ten to rupees thirty. Also, hygiene can be a concern, so be cautious about what you eat.

normalised: Finally, be mindful of your belongings. Theft can occur, especially in crowded compartments. Keep your valuables secure and be aware of your surroundings. Enjoy the scenic views and the experience!
